chapters.title: The Diagnosis
chapters.summary: Eleanor Havelock, the 78-year-old matriarch, receives a rare neurological diagnosis—Mariner's Palate—that causes her to taste ancestral memories in seawater. She is drawn to the family's abandoned whaling captain's house in New Bedford.
key_events: Eleanor experiences a vivid, disorienting 'taste' of a storm at sea while drinking tap water.
A neurologist explains her condition links taste to genetic memory, activated by sodium.
Eleanor returns to the crumbling Havelock mansion, feeling a pull to the past.
She discovers a hidden wall compartment in the study containing twelve sealed vials of seawater, each labeled with a date and a longitude/latitude.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor uncorks the first vial, brings it to her lips, and is violently plunged into the memory of her great-great-grandfather at the moment he harpoons his first whale.

chapters.title: The Prodigal Son, 1841
chapters.summary: Through the first vial, Eleanor experiences the memory of Silas Havelock, her ambitious ancestor, who commits a ruthless act to secure his first command and the family's founding fortune.
key_events: Eleanor tastes the cold Atlantic, blood, and whale oil.
She witnesses young Silas, not yet a captain, on a chaotic whaling ship.
Silas secretly sabotages the ship's compass, causing it to be lost long enough for the ailing captain to die of fever.
He then heroically navigates them home using the stars, securing his reputation and command.
chapters.ending_hook: Back in the present, Eleanor vomits saltwater, reeling from the knowledge that the family empire was built on a calculated murder.

chapters.title: The Captain's Wife, 1858
chapters.summary: The second vial reveals the story of Constance Havelock, Silas's wife, who managed the business on shore and made a brutal financial decision that doomed a rival family.
key_events: Eleanor tastes ink, salt, and bitter tea.
She experiences Constance's frustration at being land-bound while Silas is at sea for years.
Constance intercepts news of a rival whaler's sinking and uses insider knowledge to buy their debts and seize their assets before the widow is notified.
She writes a triumphant letter to Silas, cementing the Havelock monopoly.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor feels a ghostly pang of Constance's guilt, which she channeled into building the family library—a library Eleanor now sits in, surrounded by books bought with ruined lives.

chapters.title: The Castaway, 1872
chapters.summary: A vial from the Indian Ocean reveals a shameful secret of abandonment. Eleanor experiences the memory of a young deckhand, a Havelock cousin, left for dead to cover up a captain's mistake.
key_events: The water tastes of coconut, desperation, and sun-bleached wood.
Eleanor sees Captain Josiah Havelock (Silas's son) panic during a mutiny scare.
He exiles a loyal but injured cousin, Isaiah, on a barren atoll, promising to return.
The ship sails on; the promise is forgotten in the pursuit of a spermaceti-rich pod.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor, gasping, feels Isaiah's final hopeless gaze at the horizon. She finds his name later that day in the family Bible, marked only with 'Lost at Sea.'

chapters.title: The Lighthouse Keeper's Daughter, 1890
chapters.summary: A vial from the Maine coast holds a memory of stolen love and a hidden pregnancy that was erased from the family record.
key_events: The water tastes of pine, cold stone, and fresh rain.
Eleanor lives the memory of her great-aunt Flora, who fell in love with the son of a lighthouse keeper.
When Flora became pregnant, her father, a Havelock, paid off the family and had the young man shipped to the West Coast.
Flora was sent to a 'sanitarium' and returned months later, childless and hollow.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor finds a faded, hidden photograph of Flora holding an infant, and realizes she may have living relatives unknown to the family tree.

chapters.title: The Strike-Breaker, 1911
chapters.summary: A vial from New Bedford harbor reveals the memory of Eleanor's grandfather, Aldous, using violent means to break a dockworkers' strike, creating a generational rift in the town.
key_events: The water tastes of smoke, sweat, and copper (blood).
Eleanor witnesses Aldous hiring thugs to intimidate striking workers.
A fire breaks out at the picket line; Aldous orders the Havelock gates locked, trapping men inside.
He later donates to the families of the deceased, laundering his guilt into public philanthropy.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor remembers her own father's bitter, unexplained feud with the local union president—a feud whose origin she now understands.

chapters.title: The Shift
chapters.summary: Struggling with the weight of the memories, Eleanor's present-day life fractures. She confides in her estranged granddaughter, Maya, a marine biologist.
key_events: Eleanor's erratic behavior concerns her lawyer and housekeeper.
She reaches out to Maya, the only family member skeptical of the Havelock 'myth.'
She shows Maya the vials. Initially skeptical, Maya is convinced when Eleanor perfectly describes the 1872 atoll's topography.
They argue over whether to continue; Maya wants truth, Eleanor fears it.
chapters.ending_hook: Maya takes a vial to have its water chemically analyzed, seeking scientific proof of the memories' origins.

chapters.title: The War Profiteer, 1943
chapters.summary: A vial from the South Pacific reveals how the Havelocks profited from WWII, selling faulty supplies to the Navy and causing the deaths of sailors.
key_events: The water tastes of diesel, hot metal, and deep-sea pressure.
Eleanor experiences the memory of her father, Wallace, as a young executive.
He knowingly approves a shipment of substandard steel cable for naval use to meet a lucrative contract.
He later reads a report of a destroyer's loss, linked to cable failure, and files the report away in a locked drawer.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor finds the actual report, still in her father's old desk. The listed coordinates match the location of a vial she has yet to drink.

chapters.title: The Cover-Up, 1968
chapters.summary: The memory from the found coordinates reveals that Eleanor's beloved uncle didn't die in a sailing accident, but was killed for threatening to expose the wartime crimes.
key_events: The water tastes of gin, cordite, and marsh mud.
Eleanor relives a bitter argument between her father Wallace and his idealistic brother, Thomas.
Thomas, having discovered the 1943 documents, threatens to go to the press.
Eleanor experiences the memory of Thomas's 'accident' from Wallace's perspective—a deliberate push from a dock in the fog.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor collapses, not from the memory, but from the realization that her own father was a murderer. Her health begins to visibly fail.

chapters.title: The Trust
chapters.summary: Maya returns with proof: the water contains epigenetic markers and stress hormones aligned with the memories. Eleanor must decide the fate of the family's wealth and legacy.
key_events: Maya's analysis confirms the water is a biological archive of traumatic memory.
Eleanor's lawyer pressures her to sign updated estate papers to preserve the trust.
Eleanor confronts the full scope: the fortune is a monument to violence, betrayal, and blood.
She considers destroying the remaining vials and the mansion itself.
chapters.ending_hook: Eleanor decides to drink the remaining vials, no matter the cost. "I have to swallow it all," she tells Maya, "before I can be sick of it for good."

chapters.title: The Last Voyage
chapters.summary: In a feverish state, Eleanor drinks the final vials in succession, experiencing a cascading torrent of smaller cruelties, hidden joys, and quiet despair from generations of Havelocks.
key_events: The memories become a blur—a first kiss on a ship, a stolen ship's log, a wept-over letter, a moment of kindness to a cabin boy.
Eleanor understands the full human spectrum: not all were monsters, but all were complicit in the system.
She has a vision of the family line as a ship, each generation nailing the next into its rotten timbers.
Maya finds her on the floor, whispering the names of the forgotten and the wronged.
chapters.ending_hook: With her last bit of strength, Eleanor gives Maya a single, clear instruction about the Havelock Trust and the mansion.

chapters.title: Ebb Tide
chapters.summary: In the aftermath, Maya executes Eleanor's final wishes, breaking the cycle and allowing the toxic legacy to dissipate like salt in fresh water.
key_events: Eleanor's will is read: the Havelock fortune is dissolved to create a maritime historical truth commission and scholarships for descendants of whaling communities and strikers.
The mansion is donated to the city as a museum focused on the true, unvarnished history of the whaling industry.
Maya, holding the last empty vial, walks to the cliffs and scatters Eleanor's ashes into the Atlantic.
She takes a sip of fresh water from a spring, tasting only its own clean, singular self.
chapters.ending_hook: Maya looks out at the sea, no longer a haunted archive, but simply an ocean. She feels the weight lift, and for the first time, the future seems open, clear, and hers to define.
